1. Adjusting defensive strategies: Coaches can opt for a full-court press or double teams to try to force turnovers and prevent their opponents from scoring.

2. Offensive plays: Coaches may draw up new offensive plays to help their team find easier scoring opportunities, take advantage of mismatches, or create shots for their best scorers.

3. Rotating players: Coaches may choose to give additional playing time to bench players who can provide a spark, fresh legs, or a different look on the court.

4. Playing better defense without fouling: Coaches can stress the importance of playing intense defense while cutting down on fouls to prevent their opponents from getting easy points.

5. Adjusting lineups: Coaches can switch up the combinations of players on the court to maximize production and efficiency.

6. Focusing on rebounding: Coaches can stress the importance of winning the battle on the boards to get more opportunities to score and limit their opponents’ scoring chances. 

7. Managing time-out usage: Coaches can strategically use their timeouts to rest players, adjust strategies, or halt opponents’ momentum. 

8. Mental preparation: Coaches can motivate and encourage their players to stay focused, execute their game plan, and believe they can win in the final quarter.
